The Best Vegan Chow Mein

35 min

Main

share

pin

tweet

email

print

support

To effortlessly serve up this dish that outshines takeout, the secret is having all your vegetables chopped and prepped. Once you begin cooking, this recipe comes together swiftly, and with everything ready, the entire meal flows seamlessly.

Servings

Total

35 min

Prep

20 min

Cook

15 min

Contains

soy

sesame

gluten

Free from

peanut

tree nut

Gift Wellness

This holiday season, with the Pick Up Limes app!

share

pin

tweet

email

print

support

Ingredients

Sauce

  • 3 Tbsp (45 mL)
    dark soy sauce, plus more to taste
    tamari
  • 2 Tbsp (30 mL)
    water
  • 2 Tbsp (30 mL)
    toasted sesame oil
  • ½
    vegetable bouillon cube, crumbled
  • 2 tsp (5 g)
    cornstarch
  • 2 tsp (10 mL)
    agave syrup
    granulated sugar
    maple syrup
  • 1 tsp (5 mL)
    sriracha hot sauce
    sambal oelek
  • 1 tsp (5 mL)
    rice vinegar

Chow Mein Base

  • ½ Tbsp (7 mL)
    vegetable oil
  • 1 cup (168 g)
    mock "chicken" pieces, torn into shreds
  • 1 Tbsp (15 mL)
    vegetable oil
  • 1
    medium onion, thinly sliced
  • 2
    cloves garlic, minced
  • 5.3 oz (150 g)
    vegan chow mein noodles
    quick-cooking ramen noodles
    dry gluten-free noodles
  • ¼
    napa cabbage, thinly sliced
    shredded green cabbage
    shiitake mushroom
  • 2
    carrots, julienned
  • 1
    head of bok choy, thinly sliced, stems and leaves separated

Optional garnishes

  • toasted sesame seeds
  • sliced green onion
  • crispy chili oil

Directions

  1. Combine sauce ingredients in a jar or small bowl.
  2. Add the oil to sauté pan on high heat. Cook the mock chicken pieces until golden. Transfer to a plate and set aside.
  3. Add the some more oil to the now-empty pan. Cook the onion and garlic in the pan until the garlic becomes golden.
  4. Then add the cabbage, carrots, and white stems of the bok choy. Cook for 3 - 4 minutes.
  5. Meanwhile, cook the noodles according to the package directions. Then drain and rinse with cold water to stop the cooking process.
  6. Add the mock chicken back to the pan along with the bok choy leaves. Cook until warmed through.
  7. Stir through the cooked noodles, then pour over the sauce and toss to combine. Cook for 3 minutes to allow the cornstarch to thicken.
  8. Serve with green onions and sesame seeds. Enjoy!

Storage

  • Store in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days.
Print

Nutrition info

We believe that focusing on numbers can harm our relationship with food. Instead, our philosophy is to Nourish the Cells & the Soul. If you require specific nutrition information due to a medical condition, please consult with a dietitian or physician. The nutritional information provided is composed with the utmost care. Really looking forward to trying this! Any alternatives to the ½ vegetable bouillon cube?

Hey Anna, the vegetable bouillon cube and water (2 Tbsp/30 mL for 3 servings) can be substituted for equal parts vegetable stock or broth, or you can simply omit it. We'd recommend giving the sauce a taste test in this case, and adding some salt or soy sauce if you think it needs it 🙂

Reply
Lorrie McFadden - Nov. 3, 2023, 4:37 a.m.

I love your recipes. Unfortunately, I have a soy allergy and I’m always looking for alternatives for soy sauce. Any suggestions on making alternatives like coconut aminos taste more like soy in your recipes?

PUL Team - Nov. 3, 2023, 9:23 a.m.

Hey Lorrie, I'm delighted to hear that you enjoy the recipes! For a soy sauce substitute, coconut aminos is indeed a great option. To make it taste more like traditional soy sauce, you could try adding a little bit of sea salt for more of that salty depth. You could also consider using a soy-free sauce like Tamari (it traditionally contains soy but there are some soy-free options on the market). If you're looking for more complexity in the umami flavor, adding a small amount of mushroom powder can also enhance the flavour profile. Remember to adjust these additions gradually and taste as you go to find the balance that works best for you.

Lorrie McFadden - Nov. 3, 2023, 5:29 p.m.

Thank you for your speedy reply! I’m going to try some chickpea miso as it is both umami and salty and see what happens. I’ve added salt but it lacks that interest that soy sauce has. I will try it on this recipe!

Reply
EB - Oct. 9, 2023, 7:57 p.m.

What is the difference between dark and light soy sauce? Currently making this recipe. :)

PUL Team - Oct. 9, 2023, 8:57 p.m.

Hey EB, dark soy sauce is generally thicker, richer, and has a more intense flavour compared to light soy sauce. It's often used for colour and depth in dishes, whereas light soy sauce is lighter in colour and flavour, and typically used for seasoning. We hope you enjoy the chow mein ✨

Pk - Nov. 11, 2023, 9:31 p.m.

Although I have used it, I never really understood the significance of soy sauce in a dish. It has quite a salty note but other than that it doesn't have a taste that contributes to the flavor of a dish. Any insight on this?

PUL Team - Nov. 11, 2023, 10:59 p.m.

Hey Pk, soy sauce indeed offers a salty flavour but we also enjoy the umami flavours that it provides for taste and depth 😊

Hey there, Nova, thanks for sharing your experience with the chow mein! The lack of flavour could be a result of the noodle-to-sauce ratio being too high in case you might have used more noodles or a different type of noodle. Glad that the extra sauces did the trick though 😃

Lisa K - Sept. 20, 2023, 8:29 p.m.

I made this last night for me and my husband. The only change I made was to make 1.5 times the sauce. I had a LOT of vegetables and the original amount seemed just a bit scant to me. I also added some fresh mung bean sprouts to the scallion and toasted sesame seeds as a garnish. By using store-bought shredded carrots, this came together in a little over 30 minutes. I also found that my "chiken" strips didn't shred that well, so just cubed them and it worked perfectly. We actually liked that the cubes had a bit of bite that you might not get with shredding. All in all, this dish had so much flavor, great textures and was a real comfort food. So much better, fresher, lighter than restaurant Chinese food. I had leftovers for lunch and it was wonderful! I will gladly make this again.

Oh, Lisa, we appreciate you taking the time to share your experience with the chow mein! Cubed bites sound lovely for a bit of texture. Happy cooking 🫶

Guilherme Ostrock - Sept. 19, 2023, 9:37 p.m.

I was searching for an easy and quick recipe for a delicious meal, and when I came across this one claiming to be effortless, I thought I had hit the jackpot.

But alas, this recipe turned out to be more of a dream than a reality. Not because it's easy and fast (35 minutes total prep time? Really?), even tough I have at least 10 years of cooking experience under my belt. I may not be the most skilled chef, but for goodness' sake, can we at least get an accurate estimate of the preparation time, from grabbing the vegetables in the fridge to properly chopping and organizing everything?

The option to scale up the recipe is a nice touch, but did anyone bother to check if it actually works after altering the quantity of servings? It's not just about creating a widget to multiply the zeroDotSomething variable (what on earth is a 0.67 napa cabbage anyway? The world uses grams/kilograms or at least the cumbersome imperial system), if in reality, you need an industrial-sized kitchen to combine everything.

This isn't the first impractical recipe I've tried, but because my wife enjoys your site, I thought, "Let's give it a try." Nevermore.

PUL Team - Sept. 19, 2023, 10:11 p.m.

Hey there, Guilherme, I'm truly sorry to hear about your disappointing experience with the recipe and our website. We strive to provide high-quality content, so it's disheartening that we've fallen short of our standard. We appreciate you taking the time to share your concerns, it helps us improve and grow 🙂

One key to the speed provided is to organize some of the ingredients while others are cooking, such as the noodles. This is what we were hoping to highlight in the accompanying video and in the way we structured the directions. The exact weight of veggies can vary, so we've avoided putting a gram measurement for fruits/veg on our site to promote less strict measuring. This is in contrast to our baking recipes, which do require more strict measurements, so these always contain gram amounts. We've taken note of your feedback and in the meantime hope that your wife continues to enjoy our content. If you have any other concerns we can always be reached at [email protected] 💌

Shanti - Sept. 15, 2023, 11:13 p.m.

Hi Team PUL,
I always get confused when soy sauce is in the recipe. As you know Sadia, in The Netherlands we have sweet and salty soy sauce. I can never tell which one to use, because they both give a different taste. Which one is used here, please? Maybe you can give me the name of the brand so I can get that one. Otherwise I have ketjap mani, ketjap asin, and Japanese soy sauce. Not only do all three of them taste differently, but the consistency of each varies as well.

PUL Team - Sept. 16, 2023, 7:48 p.m.

Hey there, Shanti, apologies for any confusion. When we refer to soy sauce we mean the Japanese version (the salty one) and not ketjap (the sweet Indonesian variety). The Kikkoman brand is the one we use most often. Enjoy the recipe if you give it a try :)

Wim - Sept. 16, 2023, 10:33 p.m.

Hi Shanti,
I am also from Holland and I was having the same issue. I made it with the Japanse kind, because there is also agave syrup in there and I don't want this to be so sweet. It worked very well. For the rest I did stick to the recipe. I did use the less salt variety. @pickuplimes keep up the good work, you're an inspiration and made made my transition to vegan a lot easier. 🙏

Shanti - Sept. 16, 2023, 10:56 p.m.

Hi Wim, thanks for you reply and the advice. I ended up using ketjap asin because it is salty and in the video it seemed Sadia was using something with a thick consistency but also a salty accord. The agave syrup balanced it out nicely. I made it today and it was so delicious. All the best on your plant-based journey. There are so many great YouTubers out there with fantastic recipes like Rainbow Plant Life, Yeung Man Cooking, Minimalist Baker, and Plant-Based School. Gaz Oakley has wonderful videos, too. Have a great weekend!

Colette - Sept. 10, 2023, 11:10 p.m.

Omg, this is dangerously good! Will definitely be making it again. If I refrigerate the leftovers, any tips on reheating them?

PUL Team - Sept. 11, 2023, 3:15 a.m.

So happy to hear, Colette! To reheat the chow mein leftovers, we prefer to warm it up on the stove over medium-low heat with a splash of water or sauce to prevent drying, and covering with a lid helps. Otherwise, you can also microwave it in short intervals, stirring in between, until heated 😊
